<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_mkconsistent_:
```c
static int lfs_fs_mkconsistent_(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // lfs_fs_forceconsistency does most of the work here
    int err = lfs_fs_forceconsistency(lfs);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // do we have any pending gstate?
    lfs_gstate_t delta = {0};
    lfs_gstate_xor(&delta, &lfs->gdisk);
    lfs_gstate_xor(&delta, &lfs->gstate);
    if (!lfs_gstate_iszero(&delta)) {
        // lfs_dir_commit will implicitly write out any pending gstate
        lfs_mdir_t root;
        err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &root, NULL, 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
lfs_gstate_iszero(&delta);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call itself does not show a violation. Passing &delta to lfs_gstate_iszero is fine regardless of whether delta is non-const; if lfs_gstate_iszero is declared to take a const-qualified pointer (e.g. int lfs_gstate_iszero(const lfs_gstate_t *g)) then the call is correct. However, if the function is declared as int lfs_gstate_iszero(lfs_gstate_t *g) but the implementation only reads from *g (i.e. does not modify the object), then that function declaration violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 (it should accept a pointer to const).
